paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: Extracted information on the KCNH2 variant N588K, including clinical significance, penetrance data, and individual records.

patients.phenotype: Short QT syndrome (SQT1) with a corrected QT interval (QTc) of 288 ms

individual_records.phenotype_details: Short QT syndrome with a QTc of 288 ms
individual_records.evidence_sentence: KCNH2-linked short QT syndrome (SQT1) was first identified in a 51-year-old male presenting a corrected QT interval (QTc) of 288 ms.

functional_data.summary: The N588K mutation leads to an increased activity of rapid delayed rectifier potassium current (IKr) in the hERG potassium channels, resulting in a substantial gain of function during phase 2 and 3 of the cardiac action potential.
assays: in vitro standard whole-cell patch clamp recordings

variants.evidence_level: Strong evidence based on functional studies and clinical presentation.
variants.additional_notes: The variant is associated with a significant clinical phenotype of SQT1.
key_quotes: KCNH2-linked short QT syndrome (SQT1) was first identified in a 51-year-old male presenting a corrected QT interval (QTc) of 288 ms.

Results from in vitro standard whole-cell patch clamp recordings have revealed that this mutation leads to an increased activity of rapid delayed rectifier potassium current (IKr) in the hERG potassium channels.

extraction_metadata.notes: The extraction was straightforward as the paper provided clear information on the KCNH2 variant.
